ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learning ROS, state estimation, machine learning and a whole lot of other cool things!

I learned the techniques behind self-driving cars, and how to use ROS to create our own self-driving car. Computer vision, ML, LIDAR, State estimation. All useful. We didn't go into any of the topics too far in depth, but enough to get a solid understanding of them.
Self driving cars
Learned about computer vision and machine learning, as well as how to implement these techniques.
Knowledge of Python, self driving cars, and ROS
Basics of self-driving cars -- modular code, nodes that subscribe and publish to various topics. How to integrate sensor data.

I learned a lot about the fundamentals of self-driving cars, including the CARLA simulator, x-box manual control, computer vision and PID control-based lane following, Kalman Filtering and dead reckoning, machine learning-based obstacle detection, and machine learning-based lane following.

This class goes into a lot of different topics including computer vision, sensors, filtering, and some neural networks. We went through each section pretty quickly, so I usually learned only enough to complete the next part of the project. Throughout the class, you will also learn how to use the Robot Operating System (ROS) and how to construct a system for the different sensors on the car to communicate.

I learned about many of the techniques involved in self-driving cars, such as computer vision, PID control, Kalman Filters, and machine learning. Gained an appreciation for the various factors that have to be accounted for in creating self-driving cars.

This course covered many topics in sensors, image processing, machine learning and more and the way these are all integrated into self-driving car systems. It also taught students how to build physical robotic systems, from using the Robot Operating System to hardware components on the provided cars.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great course, but sometimes things could be explained better. There was some difficulty in some of the more involved things with certain machine learning techniques were not repeatable or hard to work on solo.
It's incredibly interesting and Man-Ki is really helpful. Also, building towards a concrete end product that works was awesome.
The hands-on parts of the class in were lab were very helpful in completing the assignments, but the lectures were a little hard to follow sometimes
I really enjoyed the in person lab components of the class  it was such a privilege given the mainly virtual year

Strengths: Man-ki is truly a delight and wants the best for his students. He'll stay after to help, come early, and responds lightning-fast on slack. The psets are very straightforward and useful for learning. 

Weaknesses: Be prepared for the exam to look nothing at all like the psets! The exam is math-based, and comes mostly from the lecture content. I personally think the exam should've been split up into bi-weekly psets/quizzes, so that we had a chance to practice the math / ensure we understood the content as we went along. (and then obviously have an actual exam at the end, too)

The strengths of this course include Man-Ki's extremely clear and helpful slides (including code!), well-written Github assignments, amazing helpfulness and diligence in person and on Slack, and fun lab, complete with rainbow keyboards and x-box controllers. I have no weaknesses to say - I honestly learned so much and it wasn't too much work at all.

The strengths of this class are the breadth of topics covered, the "coolness" of the projects, and the helpfulness of Professor Man-Ki. It was a lot of fun to watch the car become smarter and smarter and complete laps on the lab track. However, the breadth of the topics meant that we didn't go super deep into any one area. Labs were always a bit rushed, and especially towards the end of the class with the final project, things felt a bit disorganized.

It was a lot of fun to write code for the car and see it working. There were also a lot of interesting topics covered, albeit not too much in-depth. The lectures were sometimes a little dry, and it was often frustrating to work with machine learning, but other than that the course was good.

This course taught several really important components that go into self-driving car software systems. However many of these components felt like atomic modules. It would be helpful for contextual understanding if more time was spent investigating the connections between these different approaches and solutions to self driving.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Loved in person stuff.
It would have been helpful if the virtual lectures were recorded
Virtual class was sometimes difficult, especially the parts using CARLA

The strength of this course was the mixture of live Zoom lectures and in-person labs - we were all very fortunate to be able to attend lab in-person and see our cars perform in real-time. Virtual engagement was also very high when we had stellar guest speakers from NVIDIA and Intel talk about autonomous driving in their companies.

We had a virtual lab for the first weeks of the class, and we used a simulator to learn how to use ROS. This part of the class was as good an adaptation as we could've asked for considering the class depended on labs.

This course was very effective at creating a mix of virtual lectures and in-person labs. When going over new material the course was taught virtually. This allowed us to meet in-person to work only on the components of the class that necessitated being together.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Very interesting and useful and cool and great stuff you learn
Absolutely. For CS majors, for non-CS majors, it's just a super fun and interesting class to take.
highly.
Yes, as long as you are willing to put in the time. You get out what you put in with this class.
Pretty chill class. Not always clear why certain things work/dont work, but cool to see concepts in action. Full return to in-person should help the class too.
Yes! Its such a great CS elective

I would highly recommend this course to another student - even during COVID-19, we were able to work on programming and testing our cars in person, and it was extremely rewarding to see our cars perform lane following, obstacle detection, and traffic sign detection. I am a physics major who did not take 223, yet Man-Ki was super kind in letting me into the class and helping me throughout the semester. Anyone interested in autonomous driving who has some background in Python should take this class.

I would recommend this course to anyone who likes project/lab courses. There aren't many CS electives that require you to test out code on a physical machine, and I loved the hands-on feeling of the class. Prof Man-Ki is also great and is willing to go above and beyond to help students understand the material. The material itself was kind of all over the place which made the final difficult to prepare for, but seeing the car race around the track was definitely worth the minor headaches along the way.

Yes, definitely. You get to develop your own self-driving car and see it working. Everything is doable and Man-Ki is very helpful if things go wrong. We cover a lot of topics at the surface level, so it is a good way to expose yourself to many different things in computer science.

I would. It's a really fun and rewarding class. By the end of the semester things started to really come together and the project became really cool. Integrating driving, stop sign recognition and more happened all at the same time and within a few hours our car was very capable. One thing to note is that the workload was fairly low throughout the semester, but increased significantly towards the end of the semester, when the final projects and final presentation were due - which also co-occurred with the finals and final projects of other classes.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination of live virtual lecture, virtual labs and in-person labs.
In person lab component.
In-person lab and live virtual lecture.
Combination of live virtual lecture with in-person lab components
In person lab + virtual class
blended virtual and in-person lab
Virtual lectures and in person labs
Self-driving cars was a combination of live virtual lectures and in-person labs.
Live virtual lecture + in-person lab
The course consisted of virtual lecture and in-person labs.
